preQuizHtml:
Ah, the classic pre-activity page

  • Introduce your quiz
  • Use HTML -- pics, videos, whatever!
  • Style the way you like

GOOD LUCK!
postQuizHtml:
You finished the last level!

Well done. I'd like to congratulate you by providing this fun embedded video.

noRemainingQuestionsAtCurrentPool.preQuizText: There are no questions remaining to answer.

questions.questionHtml: True or false? Moons revolve around planets.

options.feedback: Correct, moons revolve around planets.
Moons DO revolve around planets!

questions.questionHtml: Which planet is known as the "red planet"?

options.feedback: Correct! Mars is red due to iron rusting within its dust and dirt.
It's not Venus. Venus does have a reddish-brown surface, but not nearly as red as Mars'. Mars is red due to iron rusting within its dust and dirt.
Mercury is grey! Mars is red due to iron rusting within its dust and dirt.
Neptune is a bright blue. Mars is red due to iron rusting within its dust and dirt.

questions.questionHtml: Place a checkmark beside gas giant planets.
questions.feedbackForPerfect: Correct! The rocky planets are Earth, Mercury, Venus, and Mars. Jupiter, Neptune, Saturn, and Uranus are all gas giants. Titan isn't a planet, it's a moon!
questions.feedbackForImperfect: Not quite! The rocky planets are Earth, Mercury, Venus, and Mars. Jupiter, Neptune, Saturn, and Uranus are all gas giants. Titan isn't a planet, it's a moon!

questions.questionHtml: Rank the below planets in order of their size, starting with the smallest.
questions.hintHtml: Jupiter is the biggest planet! So it should be number 4.
questions.feedbackForPerfect:
Correct!

The order, for smallest to largest, is 1. Uranus, 2. Neptune, 3. Saturn, 4. Jupiter. Jupiter is the biggest!
questions.feedbackForImperfect:
That's the wrong order...

The order, for smallest to largest, is 1. Uranus, 2. Neptune, 3. Saturn, 4. Jupiter. Jupiter is the biggest!

questions.questionHtml: Match the terrestrial planets with the number of moons they have.
questions.feedbackForPerfect: Yes! Mars and Earth have moons. Mars with two, and Earth with one. Mercury and Venus don't have any moons! üëç
questions.feedbackForImperfect: Close, but actually Mercury and Venus don't have any moons, while Earth has one and Mars has two. Good try. üëç

questionPools.feedbackOnUpgradeHtml: For the next question pool, how about you check out the mobile view? üì±

questions.questionHtml: The milky way is a #{blank} galaxy.
questions.feedbackForPerfect: Perfect! It is a 'spiral' galaxy, or a 'barred spiral' galaxy if you wanted to be more specific!
questions.feedbackForImperfect:
Hmm, that isn't right. It is a 'spiral' galaxy, or a 'barred spiral' if you wanted to be more specific!

While we're here, I wanted to demonstrate some replace strings.
  • Current Question Pool Name: #{currentPool}
  • Upgrade Pool: #{upgradePool}
  • Downgrade Pool: #{downgradePool}
  • Number of correct answers left to upgrade: #{numRemainingToUpgrade}
  • Number of incorrect answers left before you downgrade: #{numRemainingToDowngrade}

questions.questionHtml: How many planets does our solar system have?
questions.hintHtml: One was demoted to "dwarf planet" recently!

options.feedback:
There are actually 8 planets. Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune!

Pluto used to be classified as a planet, but is now considered a dwarf planet.

Here's that video again in case you wanted to check it out!

Yes! There are 8 planets. Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune!

Pluto used to be classified as a planet, but is now considered a dwarf planet.

Here's that video again in case you wanted to check it out!

There are actually 8 planets. Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune!

Pluto used to be classified as a planet, but is now considered a dwarf planet.

Here's that video again in case you wanted to check it out!

questions.questionHtml: What year was the first moon landing?

options.feedback: No, the first manned mission to the moon took place in 1969.
Yes! No the first manned mission to the moon took place in 1969.
No, the first manned mission to the moon took place in 1969.

options.optionText: We didn't land on the moon

questions.questionHtml: The largest moon of Saturn has an atmosphere that is denser than the atmosphere of Mars. The name of this moon is:

options.feedback: That's correct!
No, it's actually Titan!
No, it's actually Titan!
No, it's actually Titan!

questions.questionHtml: The speed of light in a vacuum (c) is 1,080,000,000 km/h.

options.feedback: Correct! The speed of light is a constant 1,080,000,000 km/h (299,792,458 m/s) in a vaccuum.
Actually the speed of light really is a constant 1,080,000,000 km/h (299,792,458 m/s) in a vaccuum.

questions.questionHtml: What is the estimated age of the Milky Way?

options.feedback: Yes! How did you know that?
Actually, it is 13.51 billion years!
Actually, it is 13.51 billion years!
Actually, it is 13.51 billion years!

options.feedback: Yeah, not yet. But maybe in the future!üëÄ

questions.questionHtml: Where can I find more info on this adaptive quiz tool?

options.feedback: Correct! Search for Adaptive Quiz in Confluence and you should find the page pretty easily.
Actually, Confluence is the place to go here.

questions.questionHtml: You have can as many question pools as you like.

options.feedback: Correct!
Actually, you can have as many as you want!

questions.questionHtml: Only one adaptive quiz is allowed on an HTML page. Other adaptive quizzes would need to be in an iframe.

options.feedback: Correct! You can have as many as you want.
Actually, you can have as many as you want!

questions.questionHtml: Which of the following features can be toggled on and off?
questions.feedbackForPerfect: Correct! They can all be toggled, except for randomizing the order of Question Pools.
questions.feedbackForImperfect: Not quite! They can all be toggled, except for randomizing the order of Question Pools.

options.optionText: Randomizing the order of a question's options
Randomizing the order of question pools

questions.questionHtml: How many correct answers does it take to upgrade to the next question pool?

options.feedback: There is no single number. You can choose however many questions you want!
There is no single number. You can choose however many questions you want!
There is no single number. You can choose however many questions you want!

options.optionText: There is no single number. You can choose however many questions you want!
options.feedback: Correct!

questions.questionHtml: Is the adaptive quiz accessible?

options.feedback: Yes, it has all the appropriate aria attributes, keyboard controls, and was tested with a screenreader during development.
It totally is!
